div.div: Teaching Your Child SEL Skills for Success: A Quick Guide*

article.class: entry h-entry hentry tag-parents author-life-changer-of-the-year post-type-text has-main-image clear

h1.a: Teaching Your Child SEL Skills for Success: A Quick Guide*

p.br:
Ed Dunkelblau
Director, Institute for Emotionally Intelligent Learning
International Coordinator, Academy for SEL in Schools
National Coalition for Safe Schools Board Member

div.p: What: Research shows that social-emotional skills are essential in assuring a student’s success. The school is a primary place where students develop their social-emotional abilities, but the COVID-19 pandemic has forced students to stay at home for their education. With students being at home, we still need to help them develop these relationship and self-management skills.

This is a list of questions, activities and discussion points that parents can use with their children to continue to grow their SEL skills. The questions can be modified dependent upon the student’s age and developmental level Both students and parents should answer these questions as part of the conversation.
Where can these discussions occur? During meals, after “school,” or while doing other things like chores or activities.

h2.strong: Discussion Questions (click on a category below)

ul.li: How are you feeling about being at home?
How does your body feel when you are nervous? Calm?
When you are nervous or worried, what helps you feel better?
Who do you see as the helpers during this pandemic? How you think the helpers are feeling? How can we help the helpers?
What makes your best friend special?
What do you do to feel healthy?
What is hard for you right now? How can we make it easier?
How do you express anger/frustration?
What kinds of things are harder to talk about?
How would your friends describe you?
Who do you look up to?
When you grow up, what do you want to accomplish?
What do you miss about being in school?
Who do you look up to? Why?
Who haven’t we communicated with in a while that we should reach out to?
What should we be sure and do tomorrow? This week?
How can I help you feel better when you are feeling bad?
What do you like about your cellphone/computer?
What playful things can you do on the phone when talking with friends or family?
How can I let you know that I am on your side (that you can depend on me)?
When your upset, where in your body do you feel it?
What sorts of things do you look forward to when you get back to school?
What sorts of things make you laugh?
What do you like best about being at home? Why?
How do you show people how you feel…happy, sad, angry, scared?
How do you show that you are listening when facetiming or phoning?
How is texting or speaking on the phone different than talking to someone in person?
Who do you think can use some help during this time? How might we help them?
Who are the friends that you usually talk to? Play with?
How can you contact them while you are at home? Phone, computer, letter, etc.
What is your favorite memory?
How do you handle disagreements?
What different feelings do you have when you listen to music?
How would you approach helping people who have been affected by the present situation?
How might this experience affect your life in the future?
When reading together or watching video: How was the main character feeling?, How did they handle their feelings? What would you have done?
When reading together: How did the character solve the problem? What would you do or have done ?
When playing a game: What are the rules? How does it feel to win/lose? How might others feel?
Have your child teach you something i.e. a game or something on the computer
Do puzzles together
Play games together with specific discussion of the rules and taking turns.
Play feeling pantomime or face reading
Play feelings Pictionary
Learn feelings words in another language or sign language
